Content_wSideColumn.BodyCopy:
The Theatre Summer Camp will be an excellent opportunity for those interested in theatre to explore their talents and their ability to express themselves under the helpful guidance of BYU-Idaho theatre students. Various workshops will be held on the fundamentals of theatre production. Participants will audition, rehearse, and perform as part of their experience.

Discover more about some of the key events and learning activities participants will enjoy while attending this summer:

  1. Workshops
  2. Evening Activities
  3. The Main Event

Workshops offered:

All workshops are taught by trained and experienced students in the Theatre Department. Participants will attend each workshop.

Improvisation
Learn the main principles of improvisation, and practice these principles in games and scene work taught by current and former members of Comic Frenzy.

Corrective Makeup
Get the basics on stage makeup for any production, from foundation and shadowing, to how to line your eyes and pick the right lip color.

Gore Makeup
From Zombie horror to cuts and bruises, you'll learn the basics of special effects makeup that will come in handy both on stage and at the Halloween carnival.

Audition
Knowing how to audition is the secret to a great acting career. Pick up some valuable tips on how to have the best audition possible and learn some of the basic dance steps that are sure to appear in every dance audition.

Voice Diction
Develop one of the strongest tools in your acting toolbox - your voice. This class will help you understand how breathing, posture, and other factors can

Script Analysis
Whether as an actor, director, designer, or technician, understanding the text is the first step to creating something great. Learn about objectives, tactics, beats, given circumstances, and everything else the script can tell you to make your work come alive.

Creating a Character
Walking, talking, gestures, tics, looks...all of this and more go into creating a character. Learn how to make any role you play memorable and real.

Exploration
Reading the lines isn't the only way to rehearse. Learn some new techniques that will help you discover layers of meaning beyond the words.

Principles of Design
Whether you're the director or a designer, learning how to use the basic principles of unity, harmony, contrast, variation, balance, proportion, and emphasis will take your work to the next level.

Safety
Working on a production can be dangerous sometimes, whether you're hanging lights or striking a set. Know how to keep yourself and others out of harm's way, so that the show can go on!

Stage Equipment
Ever wondered what a gobo was? Want to know how a fly system works? Find out as you explore the tools of the trade.

Etiquette/Hierarchy
"Thank you, ten." "Standby 32." "Heads!" Learn the jargon of the professional theatre world, as well as the basic rules of every theatre production and who does what in a theatre company.

Tools and Materials
Building a set, painting a prop, or hanging a light all become a lot easier when you have the right tools. Get familiar with every tool for every job.

Set Design
Put the principles of design into practice! Learn how to create powerful and usable sets for any production and any space.

Lights and Sound
Could you program the biggest sound or light board in history? Or are you not sure what the difference between a spotlight and a source-four is? Either way, learn the basics of designing and running lights and sound.

Evening Activities


Zombie Prombie
A chance to put your gore makeup skills to work and have a blast with other participants! After you've made yourself up to look like you are very accident prone, dance the night away with your fellow actors and technicians. Be sure to bring clothes that you can transform into a zombie costume!

Mystery Dinner
No rehearsal is required for this fun, delicious who-dunnit! Step into character, pick up your knife and fork, and start looking for clues. You never know...the guilty party could be sitting right next to you...

Main Event


Revue Show
The time to put it all together! Take all of the skills you've learned and put them into practice at the end of the week. Saturday afternoon, parents and friends will have the opportunity to see participants perform monologues, scene work, and even a little improv!
